channel.title: USB Capacities
channel.description:
Well, just yesterday I looked onto the properties window of both my USB's (a mini 256 MB one and a 1 GB one).
When I looked at both of their capacities it read that there was less than the original. For the 256 MB one it was about 236 MB and for the 1 GB one it was only 242 MB!
I used the error-checking tool on both USB's but it said that all was fine, no errors.
Has anything like this happened to you? If so, are there any ways you can get the capacity back to its original status? Thanks to any helpers.

item.title: USB Capacities
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Fat Cookies:

I want my broadband to be in Megabytes/second so I know how long my “stuff” should take to download without math.

For a rough guide, just knock a digit off, so 20mbit becomes 2mbyte, 8mbit becomes 800kbyte etc, it’s not accurate but it’s a ton faster than trying to work out an 8th of it.

Read full topic

item.title: USB Capacities
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

@Moparisthebest.
I get really fustrated when transfer speeds are advertised as Megabits/second when nobody measures normal data in Mb. I want my broadband to be in Megabytes/second so I know how long my “stuff” should take to download without math.

@Browserj2
I think it should be a legal requirement to clearly write that they are refering to 1000 bytes per kilobyte plus they should tell you the exact number of bytes you get in the default format.

Read full topic

item.title: USB Capacities
item.dc:creator: @cooper cooper
item.description:
@cooper wrote:

[quote=“PeterMan, post:10, topic:275056”][quote author=bowserjr2 link=topic=363383.msg2760433#msg2760433 date=1240512399]
My external harddrive is missing 44 GB (Total 640 GB), so you are right Mopar, the difference is big.
It should be illegal to write it in that way to make it looks like its have more space.
[/quote]
Couldn’t agree more.[/quote]
I agree, but capitalists are greedy, and it will probably never happen.

Read full topic

item.title: USB Capacities
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“PeterMan, post:10, topic:275056”][quote author=bowserjr2 link=topic=363383.msg2760433#msg2760433 date=1240512399]
My external harddrive is missing 44 GB (Total 640 GB), so you are right Mopar, the difference is big.
It should be illegal to write it in that way to make it looks like its have more space.
[/quote]
Couldn’t agree more.[/quote]

Well, since every storage manufacturer does that, it should be common knowledge that when you buy a 1TB harddrive that you only get 900 or so GB, you can do the math to figure out exactly how many bytes that is if you want.

Read full topic

item.title: USB Capacities
item.dc:creator: @Man_UTD_Freak Man UTD Freak
item.description:
@Man_UTD_Freak wrote:

Now, I tried re-formatting my 1 GB USB as you all said. The problem I encountered with this was that in the re-format window, in the white box under the capacity option there was only 1 option which was 242 MB.

Under ‘File System’ I changed from FAT to NTFS and the ‘Allocation Unit Size’ to default allocation size. I didn’t use the ‘Quick Format’ option either.

Remember that the capacity stayed as 242 MB, I had no option to change it. Any suggestions?

Read full topic

item.title: USB Capacities
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

You have to understand the difference in the way storage manufacturers and operating systems measure capacity. In operating systems, terms like megabyte and gigabyte refer to powers of 2, while in the hardware industry they tend to refer to powers of 10. One kilobyte in software is 2 to the 10th power, or 1,024 bytes. In hardware it’s 10 to the 3rd power, or 1,000 bytes. So for every kilobyte of storage the hardware manufacturer advertises, you are actually getting 24 bytes less of storage for your operating system. Therefore the more storage you buy, the more you ‘lose’.

Does that make sense?

Read full topic

item.title: USB Capacities
item.dc:creator: @PeterMan PeterMan
item.description:
@PeterMan wrote:

Fat Cookies:

Format them and everything should be well. Around 10% less than the orignal size is acceptable.

Yes, this on the other hand is not acceptable:

Man UTD Freak:

and for the 1 GB one it was only 242 MB!

Read full topic

item.title: USB Capacities
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

My 200GB Hard disk formated as 2.8GB FAT32 partition and a 183GB NTFS partiotion. 15GB Gone on Partion Table!
My 2GB USB Stick has around 1.8GB in FAT.

Format them and everything should be well. Around 10% less than the orignal size is acceptable.

Read full topic

item.description:

it’s the space needed to “draw” the lines on the platters.
[/quote]

Yes, the partition table takes up quite a bit of space.[/quote]

item.title: USB Capacities
item.dc:creator: @PeterMan PeterMan
item.description:
@PeterMan wrote:

[quote=“Man UTD Freak, post:1, topic:275056”]Well, just yesterday I looked onto the properties window of both my USB’s (a mini 256 MB one and a 1 GB one).

When I looked at both of their capacities it read that there was less than the original. For the 256 MB one it was about 236 MB and for the 1 GB one it was only 242 MB!

I used the error-checking tool on both USB’s but it said that all was fine, no errors.

Has anything like this happened to you? If so, are there any ways you can get the capacity back to its original status? Thanks to any helpers. [/quote]
This happens to my memory stick for PSP. I gotta delete stuff directly from the PSP. If I delete it via the computer, it gets bugged like this and I have to reformat the memory stick.

And there is your solution btw, if you don’t have anything on it, just reformat it

Also, if you have stuff on it, just back it up. But I guess that is common sense.

Read full topic

item.title: USB Capacities
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

That 2GB might have just been 2Gb, which would’ve been around 256 also. But I don’t think I’ve ever purchased anything that had it’s intended capacity.

My 30GB iPod has 29.4 GBs, 1GB USB has 991MB, 2 GB microSD has 1.79 GB, etc.

Read full topic
